segments.text: Good morning, this is Tonya with you on KOBJFM's news magazine, where our guest today is a city planner.
He's director of environmental studies at St. Edward's University.
We thought we'd ask him to talk to us a bit about Austin moving into the 21st century.
Our guest is Kevin Stowers.
Hi, Kevin.
We're real glad you could be with us today.
Well, I'm glad to be here and glad you could ask me to come out.
I've been eager to talk a little bit about Austin.
Okay.
What would you say are the major urban problems that are facing the U.S. at this point?
Essentially, all of the good and bad things that you might see in our society seem to be very much congregated in our cities.
It's kind of an obvious statement.

But on the other hand, if you stop to consider the fact that we've only been an urban society since roughly the 1940s, this is really something of significance to suddenly see that we may have to find a new future for our cities.
So are you saying that we've only been predominantly urban since the 40s here in the US?
Oh, certainly.
Really, in 1920, well over half the population
lived on farms.
And if you stop to think how many people you knew or any of us knew that grew up on farms versus how many we know today that grew up in cities, I think you can see this kind of shift in trends.
Of course, the real problems facing the United States in many cases are problems facing all cities across the world.
What are we going to do in terms of energy and technology in the future?
We're facing essentially a situation where energy consumption patterns are being forced to change.
We don't have the oil that we once had and relied on.
We've really only gone through perhaps two or three major energy technologies in the history of man.
We started out using wood.
We eventually switched to coal as wood began to run short.
And then we wound up going to oil in the 20th century.
And this isn't the first energy crisis we faced in the US, and it's not the first energy crisis in the world.
Every time we see a change in technology, we see all kinds of problems being generated because of this.
And we've generally been very unsuccessful in predicting what the future is going to have after these kinds of changes.
Well, are you saying essentially that the problems we face here in any of our cities in the U.S. then are going to be connected with the oil shortage?
Well, I think that that's one of the problems we're facing, but we can't let energy per se dominate all of our perspectives.
We've still got many of the same social and economic problems that we really only began to try to solve
with the Roosevelt administration in the 30s and 40s.
What are some examples of those?
Poverty.
We still got poverty.
We still have poor people.
In general, we always look at the population and say the older people seem to have more income problems.
They don't tend to be as well off.
And old people tend to live in cities.
With our demographics, we see in the future increasingly a larger and larger percentage of our population is going to fall in this elderly class.

And somehow we have to begin to deal with the fact that more of the workforce are less, you know, the workforce is essentially going to have to support a larger proportion of the population through Social Security, food stamps, Medicare, and a variety of other programs.
And this is going to be a very expensive proposition.
Well, maybe we're getting a little bit abstract for all of us who are living here in downtown Austin.
Let's bring it back to Austin for a moment.
What would you say are the major problems coming up in the next decade for Austin, Texas?
Well, I think you can look at the city budget or the kind of issues that were raised by the city budget debate this past month or so and see exactly what's going to be ahead of us.
There doesn't seem to be an end
in sight in terms of inflation.
I don't think it's going to be a rapidly cured event.
And that's going to affect you, it's going to affect me, it's going to affect all of us in terms of our taxes.
Because if we want to continue to have the kind of city that traditionally most of us think of Austin as being, it's not going to be an inexpensive proposition in the future.
We're growing at a tremendously rapid rate.
And among the things that are leading those inflation figures are such things as land.
And we tend to think of Austin as being a pleasant place with lots of open space, lots of parks, fairly reasonable traffic situations, clean air, clean water.
And those things don't really come cheaply.
There's an economic cost associated with those.
What currently are the bases for taxation here in Austin?
How do you get taxed in Austin now?
Well, you get taxed almost every time you turn around.
It might seem a little facetious, but at the same time, if you stop to think, every time you buy a product that is not exempt, a portion of that sales tax goes to Austin.
You get taxed through your property taxes.
They tend to have in Austin a rather extensive fee structure, which seems to be broadening in terms of its scale.

They're a pay-as-you-go philosophy that most economists would tend to support so that people recognize that there is a cost associated with playing a round of golf or being on a softball team and so forth.
All of these may not be taxes in terms of the traditional sense, but they are part of the cost of operating a city.
Well, now, do you mean to say that people who play golf are essentially being taxed?
Well, the golfer, per se, does pay a portion of what it costs to operate that golf course and maintain it.
His fee for a round of golf doesn't pay for the entire cost of maintaining that course.
Part of that comes from property taxes.
And the people that pay property taxes include not only the people who own real property, that is, a house or a lot...
but also anyone who essentially rents a residence in Austin or an apartment.
Well, how do renters end up paying the tax?
Well, because that's a cost that your landlord is not going to absorb.
He's in the business to make money, so he's got to find a way to make enough money to cover the cost of his mortgage, taxes, maintenance, and so forth.
And he's going to pass all that on in terms of how much you pay for your rent.
So is it fair then to say that the...
Increase in rents recently is a result of the increase in property taxes.
Oh, to some extent, I'm sure that's true.
But there are a lot of things that go into determining how much you pay for rent.
And taxes are probably only a minor part of it.
A much larger part is the fact that there are a lot of people moving to Austin.
It's a desirable place to live.
And if all of a sudden the occupancy rate is very high for apartments,
It's only obvious to the landlord that he can charge a higher rate.
He's going to try to charge what he can get.
So it's a supply and demand question.
It's a supply and demand question.
And part of that is taxes.
The whole question of transportation is an interesting one because I think that's a real problem in Austin.
It's going to be more of a problem in Austin.
The larger the city grows, the harder it is to get around.
You just simply have more area to cover.
You've got more territory.
You've got further distances.
And essentially, most of us don't like to spend a lot of time in our car, yet we want to be absolutely free to make every trip we desire to make.
It's obvious as the city gets larger that a couple of things have to happen.
And among them, it's likely that you're going to see more freeways being built or interstate loop radial type controlled access highways.

you're likely to see a little bit more emphasis being put into your mass transit system simply because you have a larger percentage of your population that is not going to be able to utilize automobiles in all of the trips.
And that creates also additional demands in terms of economy because, again, that has to be paid for somehow.
The federal government provides a 50% operating subsidy
to many communities for mass transit.
But the other 50% subsidy has to come from somewhere.
Some communities have chosen to do that through a sales tax that has essentially been dedicated to the purpose of supporting transit.
Other communities simply try to support it out of general revenue funds.
That's what Austin is doing.
And this is part of the problem every year, because all of a sudden, Austin comes up at the end of the budget
And we've got so many good projects that need to be carried out that there's generally going to be a higher expenditure than income.
And then the city council is faced with a very difficult dilemma.
Do we want to raise taxes or user fees in order to accommodate that?
Or two, do we want to make some cutbacks in some of these very beneficial, good programs?

the last couple of years the city council has taken the view that maybe it's better to try to cut back and minimize some of those services somewhat in order to be able to avoid general tax increases well now is that the reason why we don't really have very good mass transit here in austin well that's only part of the reason essentially
You don't tend to have what would be very good mass transit anywhere in North America, and by that you can include Mexico, Canada, as well as the United States.
The real reason we don't have good mass transit is that our cities are designed for a transportation technology that is basically balanced against low density.
In other words, we tend to emphasize the need for single family detached housing.
Everybody wants to have a little quarter acre lot or 10,000 square feet, you know, with five or 10 feet on the side yards.
Everybody wants their land.
Everybody wants a little bit of land.
And the problem is that when you have these kinds of housing patterns, that doesn't tend to effectively feed, in an economic sense, a mass transit system.
It's very suitable in terms of
an automobile, but it's not very suitable for a bus or light rail or even rapid rail, heavy rail transit.
And this is the real dilemma.
Well, what is the solution then for people who would like to be able to use mass transit but don't want to give up their suburban life?
Well, that's almost a no-win situation.
It's a double-bind situation.
I don't think you can effectively have both.
because essentially you're going to pay a very high subsidy.
You're going to have very high taxes to have good transit with large lot subdivisions, or two, you're going to have to give up the large lot subdivisions to have good transit.
Well, are you visionary enough to imagine another way of building our city instead of in suburban lots?
Well, I don't have to be visionary, particularly because people have been writing about this for essentially at least 30 or 40 years.
There are alternatives, but we have to understand that the economies of scale, the capacity of transit systems vary according to how many people you can expect to get on in a given area.
In other words, how many people can feed a station.
Now, if you look at our average southwest United States city, we don't tend to have the kind of land use patterns that accommodate that.
We tend to have
If a typical subdivision is maybe a mile square, we might have 1,000 houses there.
And so we've got maybe 2,300, 3,000 people living there.
That's just not enough to effectively operate a mass transit system.
Even if we run a bus through it, that still means there's a good chance somebody's going to have to walk a quarter or a half mile to get to it.
And people don't like to walk that far.

The alternative is probably going to be that we're going to see more garden apartments, townhouses, and that can support a more frequent transit system, whether it's a light rail or an effective bus system.
And I think buses can do a very fine job of not advocating any particular form of transit.
What it means is that we're simply going to have to see more people in our cities living
in a higher density pattern if we're going to have effective transit.

I think given a very high cost of housing, which has essentially excluded at least 60% and probably close to 80% or 90% of the American families out of traditional housing, combined with the energy shortage, we're going to see eventually a change in the direction of development in the future.
We're going to continue to see low-density development because there will always be those who can afford it.
But we're not going to have people being able to afford that in terms of the mass traditional sense of the American culture.
I'm sorry, go ahead.
I was going to say that traditionally the high point in terms of effective take-home pay for most workers was during the 1960s.
In terms of effective purchasing power, they've never earned as much since.
Oh, I didn't know that.
I wasn't making too much in the 1960s, so I guess I just missed out.
You missed out on the peak.
But essentially, with inflation and the cost of living increases that most workers have been given, their buying power today is generally less than it was in, say, 64 or 67.
Oh, is that right?
It's disappointing, isn't it?
I can assure you it's disappointing because I wasn't making very much in 64.
One of the things about Austin now is that there are still quite a lot of open spaces still available to us, even though it's getting big and there's a lot of people moving in.
We have, for example, Town Lake.
We have a place where within just a short drive you can be essentially in a natural setting.
Do you see those kinds of areas being planned into the Austin of the future?

Well, let me say that I think that despite some of our disappointments and traumas that we see when the city council meets, I think overall the city council and the city staff has really done a fairly good job.
They've got a lot of limitations, they've got a lot of conflicts, but you see a lot of forward-looking thinking.
The Parks Department, for instance, does tend to have some very good people on its staff.
tend to be very oriented toward developing parks for the future.
Now, one of the real complaints is that, gee, we don't see parks being developed.

Well, part of the reason is they're spending so much of their money on acquisition of land, because they know if they don't get the land today, given the difficulties of the economy, there is very little chance they're going to effectively acquire the land
or at least the necessary quantity of land in the future.
And they are making an effort.
And they are making a definite effort to do that.
Oh, that's great, isn't it?
And this is one area which the city voters have traditionally always supported in terms of rather heavy referendum turnouts, that they will vote to spend money to acquire parkland.
And I think that that's something that's necessary if we're going to maintain...
quality associated with Austin that a lot of us tend to think back and remember, say, from the late 60s or early 50s or whenever it was that you happen to remember your favorite Austin as being.
Well, then, do you think that there...
Does the city of Austin seem to be taking into account the idea that we're going to have to have more density, more apartments, more condominiums?
Well...
Yes, but see, the real problem is where are you going to put those, because you tend to get a lot of resistance from existing landowners and existing property owners.
There is a lot of conversion going on.
There is a lot of infill housing.
You see a fair amount of apartments being built.
I think the city staff recognizes this, and I think in general the city staff and the city council are very aware that
Most of us, perhaps, or many of us, cannot afford to continue to buy a four-bedroom house with a swimming pool out back.
And there is a real concern that we've somehow got to fulfill the housing needs of the population.
And one of the ways to do that is through lower economical housing styles, and that is higher density by definition.
There doesn't seem to be as much willingness traditionally among most
homeowners to have a townhouse or condominium or apartment go in across the street from them.
And they have some very legitimate concerns, one of which is property values.
And this is one of the reasons you see neighborhood associations being formed.
They are very concerned that in some cases the entire character of their neighborhood is being changed radically and that there is too much attention being paid
to the needs of these newcomers or to the needs of speculators and developers.
And I can sympathize with both sides.
I don't think it's an easy solution for a city councilman to go one way or the other.
There has to be a balance between the two.
And I think that inevitably what you tend to see is an increasing percentage of your housing stock being devoted to multifamily housing.
Now, I could well be wrong in this because the traditional direction of most urban development has always been toward a decentralization, toward lower densities.
Part of the problem is the U.S. Census Bureau hasn't really told us what that 1980 census said.
We have some ideas what it probably said, but traditionally from 1940 to 50 to 60 to 70, continually,
Cities tended to be centralized, they tended toward lower densities.
The city of Austin has a viable downtown, and I don't mean to discourage that notion, but on the other hand, it is certainly a changing downtown, and it's much less important to
Travis County as a whole or the city of Austin as a whole than it was perhaps 20 or 30 years ago.
So you see, another issue for Austin in the future might be to maintain the trend toward revitalizing the Austin downtown.
Oh, absolutely.
This is KOBJ-FM's News Magazine, and we're speaking today with Kevin Stowers, who is the Director of Environmental Studies at St. Edward University and a city planner by profession.
Kevin, why don't you give us sort of a summary
of what you see as the major concerns for Austin as we move into the future, when you look at it from the city planner's viewpoint?
Well, I think that there are essentially perhaps five or six kind of major concerns we have to have.
One deals with economics.
Can we maintain an effective and efficient and economical city government?
And at the same time, maintain the quality
of Austin that we would all like to see.
And in terms of quality, we can talk in terms of a variety of issues.
There are frequent community hearings at various levels.
And if you see a proposal for a zoning variance being granted, the city is very active and concerned about trying to get input.
They put little signs out front saying, call this number if you're interested because we're getting ready to see something happen on this piece of property.
You ought to call.
You ought to make your opinion known.
And most of our neighborhoods have neighborhood organizations.
Find out who they are and where they are and go to the meetings.
Because the future of your neighborhood, your children, your property is really very much at stake.
And perhaps you don't agree with everything I've said or see happening in the future.
But it's up to you to be involved and make sure that your views are represented.
Because if you don't, the future of Austin may not be really what you would like it to be.
Kevin, what would you say you would like to see happen?
What would you call a good Austin in the future?
Well, I think that there are perhaps two or three things that I think that are essential for our future.
One is that I think that it's imperative that we have a good, effective transit system.
I don't think that given the direction of the energy problem that we see today that we should be in a position of being concerned from a year-to-year basis where the money for transit is coming from.
I think we have to have a dedicated source of revenue for that purpose.
I think we need a more frequent transit service and expanded routes.

i also think that we effectively have to maintain our park system our library system the cultural life of austin essentially what has made austin unique in character i can't tell you how often when somebody moves to austin i've been told they said they've been told
that, gee, you're going to really like Austin.
It's really a nice place.
It's a good place to live.
There are lots of nice things about it.
And I don't think any of us want to lose that through economy.
And by economy, that would be false economy.
I think we ought to be efficient.
I think we ought to be effective and professional.
But I don't think we want to lose the essential character of Austin.
And I think if we began to cut back and
particularly open space, environmental quality, we're going to begin to lose some of that unique character.

Well, I'd have to agree with you completely, but maybe the devil's advocate would say, well, where are we going to save money when the budget is so high that people can't afford to pay their taxes anymore?
Well,
There are always people that can't afford to pay taxes.
I would like to know exactly which individuals so I can be sympathetic with them and try to figure something out.
The elderly now have tax exemptions available.
They may not be as much as they should be, but it's certainly a beginning step.
Food is tax exempt.
It should be.
There are states in the union where the sales tax does exist on food, and I'm glad it doesn't in Texas.
medical care is exempted.
There is an attempt to exempt at least some of the most essential things.
I think the idea of a lifeline rate in terms of utilities would be very beneficial for Austin because we see essentially the tradition of utilities is to encourage consumption.
Many of our rates and many

utilities across the nation are designed essentially with the intent of encouraging an increase in consumption i don't think that's proper today given our energy problems i think we need to encourage conservation and by effectively encouraging people to use less electricity and giving breaks to those small users we can help some of those people that are having problems
with their income and their budgets.
And I think that's one area that we can give some assistance in.
So you're essentially saying that it is possible to keep the good life in Austin and not have it taxed to death?
Well, I hope it is.
It's more of a statement of faith on my part at this stage, but I think it is.
Well, this has been enjoyable.
Got a few new thoughts to think about in terms of Austin, Texas, and I appreciate very much you being with us today.
Thank you so much.
Thank you for having me.
This is Tonya Wells.
I've been speaking with Kevin Stowers on KOBJ-FM's News Magazine.
